text: well we're spending tens of billions of
pounds but I've added to that still
further by making savings elsewhere in
government and crucially selling some of
the buildings in the land that
government doesn't need now to build for
the future and that this is all about
Britain taking the bold decisions to
provide security and jobs for the next
generation to make sure we've got the
railways and the roads and the runways
that are going to power our economy
going forward and you know we're not
been very good at that as a country
under all governments we've made a start
now and there's a lot of Road building a
railway building going ahead but I want
to continue that with this independent
infrastructure commission and you can't
get agreement on these things if you
just try and do it as a Conservative
Party or a Labour Party so I'm trying to
create a cross-party consensus and I've
got an independent chair now in Android
onus who's giving up being a Labour peer
and he's going to chair this body and
that will help us as a nation come to
these collective decisions and what's it
mean sort of in practical terms as well
then you talk about powering through and
does it will it make it more difficult
for perhaps councils and residents to
stop major planning issues well let's
take a good example you know Here I am
in Manchester and there's a lot of talk
about a high-speed link we could build
between Manchester and Leeds that would
dramatically improve transport on a on a
corridor that everyone knows is badly
congested you know this infrastructure
Commission one of its first tasks is
going to be to look at that problem and
yes look if if we have a plan that this
commission comes forward with and the
the democratically elected government is
in favor of it then we can get on and
build it and of course there's always
going to be people who don't like new
building don't like new roads doing like
new railways near them but the truth is
if we hadn't built railways in the past
or motorways in the past that would have
been a disaster for this country and it
would be a disaster for this country if
we stop building now so for example
let's just take one if we would you know
somebody's house is on that corridor
what happens to them well we've got to
make a decision on where to put new
high-speed rail lines once the route is
decided obviously some people are
affected their homes are affected we pay
Jen
compensation to them but in the end I
asked you the question if we had never
built the m25 or the m6 or the Channel
Tunnel or the mate you know west coast
main line where would we be as a country
and all of those projects were bitterly
contested at the time and it's a lesson
for us as a country that the future
favors the bold if it favors countries
in this world who take these decisions
to provide jobs and living standards for
the future and I'm determined whether
it's building the right infrastructure
or getting our public finances into
shape or getting us out of the banking
system as I've just announced with
Lloyds Bank we're going to take the
decisions that deliver security and
opportunity for working people in this
country and does that mean as well you
talked about where some of the money
will come from getting money from
foreign companies well to build this
infrastructure well I'm all in favor of
attracting investment from around the
world to Britain and the exciting thing
is that Britain is now one of the
number-one destinations for that
investment and indeed the north of
England where I am today is one of the
number-one destinations in England for
that investment that's great news I'll
tell you why if there's Chinese money
coming in or American money or French
money or whatever it is coming into this
country that's money we don't have to
stump up as taxpayers yes and that's a
good deal for Britain you say so we want
to carry on making those investments you
mention that's the sort of northern
powerhouse that idea what about for the
people in red car who's the company that
they were employed by is not from this
country 1,700 of them now without jobs
yeah and of course that is an absolutely
tragic situation we worked with the
company to see if there was an
alternative the truth is steel mills are
closing all around Europe and all around
the world at the moment as the demand
for steel drops away so what can
government do in a situation like that
we can absolutely step in there with a
huge package of support for the local
community and Teesside affected by this
terrible decision we're putting 80
million pounds in to help grow
businesses there to help retrain people
to give people financial support as then
when they lose their job there so I
think that's a great example of a
country having the resources to help
when you have an individual tragedy like
closure of a steel mill but it's in the
context and you can only afford that as
a country of an economy that is growing
creating many millions of jobs over the
last couple years and many millions of
opportunities therefore for working
people including those who haven't had
work let's talk about and working people
let's talk about plans cuts as well to
tax credits we have an example I'm at
the BBC Rosa Walden a single mother of
two worked full-time says she's gonna
lose ten percent of her income around
2600 pounds to children aged 12 and 7
doesn't get any financial help from
their father she's facing cuts to her
tax credits are you in danger of hurting
people like her who are striving to work
well I want to help Rosa and families
like her who are working hard for our
country's future and what I'm offering
is a new settlement lower welfare bills
but also lower taxes and a higher wage
bill with a new national living wage and
it comes as a package along with other
things like free childcare and it means
our country lives within its means it's
that's the Economic Security I can offer
Rosa we don't have a welfare bill this
country can't afford but she'll see
higher wages she'll see help with
childcare there children of the right
age and she'll see lower tax bills so it
comes as a package and when you put it
together as a package that's what it was
in the budget I presented then the
average working family was someone
working full-time on the minimum wage is
better off and not just a little bit
better off but over 2,000 pounds a year
better off I'm interesting to see you
there and I understand from speaking to

I feel completely focused on doing this

to the small investors in our country
who put money into the banks when they

we've just talked about these important

living
and as a higher that is my job and
